name: Capitol Reef National Park
description: Located in south-central Utah in the heart of red rock country, Capitol Reef National Park is a hidden treasure filled with cliffs, canyons, domes, and bridges in the Waterpocket Fold, a geologic monocline (a wrinkle on the earth) extending almost 100 miles.
shortDescription: Located in south-central Utah in the heart of red rock country, Capitol Reef National Park is a hidden treasure filled with cliffs, canyons, domes, and bridges in the Waterpocket Fold, a geologic mono...

operatingHours.description: Capitol Reef is a 24 hour park, open all day, every day. The visitor center is open daily, except for some major holidays. Visitor center hours vary, call 435-425-3791 and follow the prompts for current visitor center information.

fees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle
fees.description: An entrance fee is charged per vehicle.

fees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle
fees.description: Valid for 7 days. Admits up to 2 private, non-commercial motorcycles with up to 4 total passengers.

fees.title: Entrance - Per Person
fees.description: Admits one individual with no car. Typically used for bicyclists and pedestrians.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Per Person
fees.description:
Commercial Road-Based Tours are required to obtain a Commercial Use Authorization before visiting Capitol Reef.

When visiting the park, the tour must then pay the separate entrance fee at the visitor center (or through pay.gov).

Tours with vehicle capacity of 15 or less should apply for a CUA in the "Guided Interpretive Tours" category. Tours of this size fall under the Guided Activities entry fee structure.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus
fees.description:
Commercial Road-Based Tours are required to obtain a Commercial Use Authorization before visiting Capitol Reef National Park.

When visiting the park, the tour must then pay the separate entrance fee at the visitor center (or through pay.gov).

Vehicle capacity of 16 seats or greater: $100.00 entrance fee

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach
fees.description:
Commercial Road-Based Tours are required to obtain a Commercial Use Authorization before visiting Capitol Reef National Park.

When visiting the park, the tour must then pay the separate entrance fee at the visitor center (or through pay.gov).

Vehicle capacity of 16 seats or greater: $100.00 entrance fee

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Per Person
fees.description:
Guided Activities include all types of guided services, such as bike and motorcycle tours, hiking guides, photography classes, hiking shuttles, and road-based commercial tours with vehicles <16 capacity.

Guided activity groups are charged the per person fee of $10.00 per client, excluding the trip leader or guide. If a client has an America the Beautiful Resident pass (annual, senior, access, etc.) it covers 4 people in the group. (Non-resident annual passes cover only the pass owner.)

climate.weatherDescription: Weather is posted daily; check at the park visitor center for weather updates. Do not enter into narrow canyons if there is a threat of rain or if rain has been falling in the area. Rain and snow may also make dirt roads impassable to vehicles.

images.title: Gifford House and Pendleton Barn
images.altText: Wingate Sandstone cliffs behind historic barn and farmhouse
images.caption: Windgate sandstone towers above historic Fruita farms and homes

images.title: Hickman Bridge
images.altText: A hiker stands beside Hickman Bridge, a natural sandstone bridge
images.caption: Hickman Bridge, a natural sandstone bridge, is a popular hike in the park.

images.title: Strike Valley
images.altText: Exposed layers of rock in the Waterpocket fold
images.caption: The Strike Valley shows colorful layers in the Waterpocket fold.

images.title: Capitol Reef Visitor Center with "The Castle"
images.altText: Cliffs known as "The Castle" tower above the Capitol Reef Visitor Center
images.caption: The Capitol Reef Visitor Center sits below cliffs known as "The Castle".

images.title: Capitol Reef Peach Orchard
images.altText: Fruit tree with peaches in front of red sandstone cliffs
images.caption: The Capitol Reef Orchards, planted in the pioneer era, remain a popular place for visitors today.
